newsitem.title: INDIA: India rupee convertibility linked to trade deficit.
newsitem.headline: India rupee convertibility linked to trade deficit.

text.p: India will not make the rupee fully convertible until its trade deficit turns into a surplus, the country's commerce minister told the Press Trust of India (PTI) on Saturday.
People are talking about full convertibility, but I do not think it is feasible as we recorded a trade deficit of about $ 5 billion," the news agency quoted B.B. Ramaiah as saying.
PTI said that the minister wanted India to start generating trade surpluses first.

It added that Ramaiah disfavoured devaluation of the rupee in favour of exporters, stating that a downward adjustment would significantly raise import bills for oil, fertilisers and other essential commodities.
The minister expressed concern over India's export performance, saying that while India was exporting wheat, sugar and edible oils, it had become an importer of foodgrains, PTI said.
The commerce minister's comments come weeks after India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India released a report recommending convertibility by 2000.
